title: The Mystery of Trumpâ€™s Man in Moscow: Carter Page
summary:
In March, in a bold â€œOh yeah?â€ moment during an interview with the Washington Postâ€™s editorial board, Donald Trump took the paperâ€™s dare and revealed, then and there, his very short list of foreign policy advisers. There were just five, though he said, â€œI have quite a few more.â€ The list was a head-scratcher, a random assortment of obscure and questionable pundits. One of the names, offered without elaboration, was, â€œCarter Page, PhD.â€

Who?

Story Continued Below

Reporters quickly Googling found that Page is the founder and managing partner of an investment fund called Global Energy Capital, and that he claims to have years of experience investing in Russia and the energy sector. As for his connection to Trump, when Page was reached for comment by the New York Times the day after Trumpâ€™s big reveal, he said he had been sending policy memos to the campaign and the paper said he â€œwill be advising Mr. Trump on energy policy and Russia.â€

This piqued my interest: I have been a Russia wonk for most of my adult life, I spent years living and reporting from Moscow, still go there regularly for reporting trips, and am in touch with lots of friends there. And yet, despite the tightly knit nature of the expat business community in Russia, no one I spoke to had ever heard of Carter Page.

â€œWhatâ€™s this guyâ€™s name?â€ says one former Western energy CEO who spent years in Russia, and would have overlapped there with Page.

â€œI had not heard of Carter Page before it came out in the media,â€ says another prominent Western businessman who has worked in the former Soviet Union for over two decades. â€œBut I am getting a lot of emails from friends asking, â€˜Have you heard of this guy?â€™â€

â€œStrangely, I've never heard of Carter Page until this Trump connection,â€ Bill Browder responded to me in an email. He was one of the biggest Western players in the Russian market until President Vladimir Putin turned on him and Browder became his fierce critic. â€œIt's odd, because I've heard of every other financier who was a player on Moscow at the time.â€

Someone, apparently, has heard of him: On Friday, Yahoo News reported that Page was being probed by U.S. intelligence for purported back-channel ties to Russian leaders. The story resurfaced the name of a character whoâ€™d all but vanished from the campaign, and reawakened questions about who, exactly, Trump was surrounding himself with.

This has been a concern swirling around the outsider candidate since he began, a real-estate developer with almost no serious Washington connections to tap for advice. â€œIâ€™m going to surround myself only with the best and most serious people," Trump famously told a Post reporter last summer about how he would staff his campaign. "We want top-of-the-line professionals.â€ As the primaries unfolded, it became increasingly obvious that Trump would need all the top-of-the-line help he could get when it came to foreign policy. In an interview with conservative radio host Hugh Hewitt, Trump confused the Kurds with the Iranian Al-Quds Force, couldnâ€™t tell the difference between Hezbollah and Hamas, and couldnâ€™t recognize the name of the leader of ISIS. (In his defense, Trump said that â€œHugh was giving me name after name, Arab name, Arab name, and there are few people anywhere, anywhere, that would have known those names.â€) The Republican foreign policy specialists who would normally be a brain trust began slamming him in the press or publicly signing on to anti-Trump manifestos. And since they increasingly were fleeing the candidate, who were the people who would line up to advise him instead? What would they be like?

Enter Carter Page, a 44-year-old Ph.D., and business school graduate who claims an expertise in Russia and energy, yet who, I quickly discovered, was known by neither Russia experts nor energy experts nor Russian energy experts. (â€œI can poll any number of people involved in energy in Russia about Carter Page and theyâ€™ll say, â€˜Carter who? You mean Jimmy Carter?â€™â€ says one veteran Western investor in Russian energy.) Page also, as I would be surprised to discover, appears largely unknown to Trumpâ€™s own campaign.

What I did find, however, is that while Page might not be helping Trump, Trump has been a significant help to Page. Since being named by Trump as an adviser, Page, who has spent his career trying to put together energy deals in Russia and the former Soviet Union, has finally begun to be noticed in the region. He is being treated in Russia as a person with potentially important ties in America. â€œHeâ€™s an extremely well-informed, authoritative expert on Russia,â€ says Mikhail Leontiev, a pro-Kremlin talking head and spokesman for Rosneft, Russiaâ€™s state oil giant. â€œPeople really respect him in this industry. Heâ€™s a very serious guy, and he has a good reputation.â€ According to the Yahoo report, U.S. intelligence believes Page had an audience with top Russian officialsâ€”including Rosneft head Igor Sechinâ€”during a summer trip to Moscow. From what I could find about him, itâ€™s hard to imagine he could have secured those meetings without that mention by Trump.

Page has also been the subject of some breathless coverage in the American press. A March Bloomberg profile touted his â€œdeep tiesâ€ with â€œexecutives at Gazprom,â€ the state-owned Russian gas giant, whom he says he advised on some of its biggest deals of the past decade. Last month, the Post ran a piece that was breathless in a different way, casting him as a shadowy broker with potentially important ties in Russia, some of them unsavory. The Yahoo story also portrays Page as a well-connected, high-rolling businessman with â€œextensive business interests in Russiaâ€ and an office â€œaround the corner from Trump Tower.â€

Page has fueled all this by making some remarkable statements, including saying Putin is a better leader than President Barack Obama to a June closed-door meeting of foreign policy Brahmins in Washington. In July, in Moscow, he spoke at the New Economic Schoolâ€™s commencement ceremony, a university that had hosted Obama just seven years ago. Page used the speech to slam the â€œhypocrisyâ€ of American foreign policy in front of a Russian audience, saying, â€œWashington and other Western powers have impeded potential progress through their often hypocritical focus on ideas such as democratization, inequality, corruption and regime change.â€ He is now frequently quoted on Russian television, which hails him as a â€œfamous American economistâ€ and â€œadviser to Donald Trump on questions of foreign policy.â€

All of which reveals something deeply strange about Trump: when he shoots from the hip, his remarks do more than just whip up Twitter controversies. They also occasionally and unintentionally mint a new species of â€œinsiders,â€ people who seem to be in Trumpâ€™s orbit but who may not haveâ€”and may never have hadâ€”any access to the gilded inner sanctum at all.

But someone is paying attention. As I started looking into Page, I began getting calls from two separate â€œcorporate investigatorsâ€ digging into what they claim are all kinds of shady connections Page has to all kinds of shady Russians. One is working on behalf of various unnamed Democratic donors; the other wonâ€™t say who turned him on to Pageâ€™s scent. Both claimed to me that the FBI was investigating Page for allegedly meeting with Igor Sechin and Sergei Ivanov, who was until recently Putinâ€™s chief of staffâ€”both of whom are on the sanctions listâ€”when Page was in Moscow in July for that speech.

So the question continued to linger: Who is Carter Page?

***

I should tell you before we get any further that Page wouldnâ€™t talk to me for this story. I called his fund and left messages, both on the general line and his personal voice mail. I emailed him repeatedly. I asked the Trump campaign to put me in touch. I emailed the Bloomberg journalist who interviewed him, who passed the request on. I even called Carter Pageâ€™s father in Poughkeepsie, New York, who told me he would ask his son to talk to me. But alas, no dice.

This was disappointing: No one who worked in Moscow when Page was there seemed to know who he was, and I just wanted to talk to someone who did. At a certain point, I just needed confirmation that he even existed.

OK, I thought. Try a different route. Maybe all these prominent Western businessmen who worked in Russia for decades didnâ€™t know Page, but maybe it was because some of them worked in different spheres of the Russian economy. He did, after all, have such an impressive rÃ©sumÃ©.

Pageâ€™s biography on the website of his energy fund, Global Energy Capital, hits all the right notes. It was, at first glance, the rÃ©sumÃ© of an up-and-coming player in the opaque but lucrative Russian energy market. â€œHe spent 7 years as an investment banker at Merrill Lynch in London, Moscow and New York where he most recently served as Chief Operating Officer of the Energy and Power Group,â€ his bio reads. â€œHe was involved in over $25 billion of transactions in the energy and power sector. He spent 3 years in Moscow where he was responsible for the opening of the Merrill office and was an advisor on key transactions for Gazprom, RAO UES and others.â€

Those were some of the biggest energy deals of the 2000s, and Pageâ€™s tenure in Merrill Lynchâ€™s Moscow office, from 2004 to 2007, would have put him in the right place at the right time. He says he was part of the carving up of RAO UES, a massive Russian electric power holding company. He told Bloomberg that he advised Gazprom when it bought a stake in the Sakhalin II oil and gas project. Those were huge, huge things. If he were deeply involved, he would definitely count as a player. And surely he left at least a trace in the records of those deals.

So I called Ian Craig, the CEO of Sakhalin Energy from 2004 to 2009, who was doing the negotiations with Gazprom and stayed on as CEO after the deal went through. (It wasnâ€™t really a deal, to be clear: Sakhalin II was a large project in the Far East, and Gazprom essentially elbowed its way into the project when the government forced the consortium to sell the gas giant a controlling stake.) But Craig said he didnâ€™t know anyone named Carter Page. He was also surprised to hear about Merrill Lynchâ€™s purported involvement in the deal. â€œI donâ€™t think Merrill Lynch or anyone else was front-lining the negotiations, because it was all done at the highest level, because it was very political,â€ says Craig . â€œIt closed at CEO level, and eventually Putin himself signed off on it.â€

When I asked a prominent Western businessman, who has worked in the former Soviet Union for over two decades and who is said to socialize with Sechin and other members of the Russian elite, about Pageâ€™s claim to Bloomberg that he advised Gazprom on Sakhalin II, he said, â€œI rolled my eyes at that one.â€ (He, too, said he hadnâ€™t heard of Page until Trumpâ€™s announcement.)

Fine. OK. Maybe Page exaggerated a bit on that one. But what about the reorganization and privatization of RAO UES, the Russian electricity giant? Maybe some of the Russians he worked with remembered a Carter Page?

Turns out, they did.

â€œHis nickname was stranichkin,â€ from the Russian word stranichka, or â€œlittle page,â€ says Artem Torchinsky, who met Page during the breakup of RAO UES. Torchinsky, who was part of the companyâ€™s financial department, worked alongside Page, who, at the time worked in Merrill Lynchâ€™s Moscow office. It was 2007, and Merrill Lynch was underwriting the sale of one part of RAO UES, and Torchinsky was resentful of Page and the other Merrill Lynchers: Torchinsky and the in-house team did all the work, and Page and his team would swoop in to give the presentation. They were the fancy Western window dressing. â€œIt really irritated our team,â€ Torchinsky told me over Skype. â€œWe worked around the clock, and then they would come in and say something incomprehensible and weâ€™d have to correct them. These guys didnâ€™t know what they were talking about.â€ As for Page, â€œHe made no impression whatsoever. Whether he was there or not, it made no difference,â€ Torchinsky says. â€œWhen youâ€™re dealing with a pro, you see it. Page, unfortunately, did not leave that impression.â€

OK, harsh. But then I talked to Pageâ€™s former boss, former Russian Central Bank Chairman Sergei Aleksashenko, who ran the Moscow office of Merrill Lynch for part of the time Page worked there. â€œHe wasnâ€™t great and he wasnâ€™t terrible,â€ Aleksashenko says, exasperated and confused by the interest of all these journalists pestering him for information about someone â€œwithout any special talents or accomplishments,â€ someone who was â€œa gray spot.â€ â€œWhat can you say about a person who in no way [is] exceptional?â€ he asked me.

Page was a vice president at Merrill Lynch in Moscow, which sounds senior but is a common title in the finance world; a big firm like Merrill Lynch might have thousands of VPs. In the Moscow office, there were five ranks, and VP was right in the middle. In effect, it was â€œjust the oldest of the youngest, three from the bottom,â€ says Aleksashenko.

When it came to finance, Aleksashenko says, Page â€œwas not a specialist in any branches of finance or in any instruments.â€ When it came to energy, Page and his team were, according to Torchinsky, â€œmildly speaking, not competent in the field of energy.â€ And, says Aleksashenko, â€œjudging by the drivel he spews on Russia, you can tell he doesnâ€™t really understand the topic.â€

Trumpâ€™s putative adviser on Russia and energy and foreign policy, in other words, â€œdid not create the impression of someone who was intellectual or well-educated, or someone who was in any way interested or knowledgeable in foreign policy,â€ says Aleksashenko.

***

For the past few years, Page has styled himself a foreign policy expert. He has written columns in Global Policy Journal, a new peer-reviewed journal run out of Durham University. They are confoundingly written and make logically curious leaps. â€œIn recent months, renewed calls for equal justice have brought social tension across the United States after the killing of Michael Brown and Eric Garner by police officers in Missouri and New York respectively,â€ he wrote. â€œAlthough commonly overlooked, the impact of other fatal mistakes by government officials in the foreign policy arena might vastly outweigh these tragic deaths in potentially catastrophic proportions.â€ He is the kind of thinker who writes that Kanye Westâ€™s â€œNew Slavesâ€ and the â€œartistâ€™s creative work offers valuable ideas that could fundamentally improve the direction of U.S. foreign policy and world affairsâ€ but does it by opening with a citation from the Oxford English Dictionary (â€œSlave; Pronunciation: /slÄv/â€¦â€), roping in Adam Sandler, William F. Buckley and Dick Cheney.

His speech in Moscowâ€™s New Economic School was a similar construction of empty spaces held together with repetition, tautologies, and abuses of the word â€œironically.â€ â€œFor the last 15 years, Iâ€™ve been researching, teaching, and writing about fundamental trends in the world economy, which have really continued to evolve in this period and in the years immediately preceding it,â€ he began. The video of the speech also suggests that after three years living there and a lifetime studying the place, he couldnâ€™t really speak Russianâ€”he had to have his questions translated for him into English. Except to quote, haltingly, brokenly, Vladimir Putin: â€œWe never meddle in the internal political affairs of other countries. Unlike the USA.â€ Which is troubling for two reasons: that the adviser of a presidential candidate of a major party is criticizing America abroad by citing Putin, and that the comment implied that he seemed to not know anything about anything going on in, say, Syria or Ukraine.

Page also managed to find his way into a fellowship at the Council on Foreign Relations, where he cut a strange figure. Like other Westerners doing business in Russia, Page took the view that Putin was not the blood-stained and corrupt tyrant some in the West imagine him to be, defending him as a strong leader who brought order and prosperity to Russia. But unlike other entrepreneurial defenders of Putin, people at the Council recall that Page was not particularly good at it. â€œHe had a guilty-seeming style in making these arguments, making it seem like he didnâ€™t really want to engage,â€ one person from the Council says. His columns made the rounds and raised eyebrows. â€œThat blog post about the slaves. Thatâ€™s just â€¦ strange,â€ says the Council member.

â€œHeâ€™s a nice guy, but of the people that I know that have Russian foreign policy experience or access and contacts, he wouldnâ€™t be in the last decile, but heâ€™d be in the second-to-last decile,â€ says one American executive with experience in Russia and its energy sector. â€œYouâ€™d have to dip really far and wide to find a guy like Carter Page. I mean, wow.â€

***

I shouldâ€™ve just dropped the Carter Page story, but in the months since Trump named him an adviser, the campaignâ€™s Russia connections have become a bigger and bigger issue. Fancy Bear, who was probably a Russian hacker, broke into the Democratic National Committee emails, seemingly handed them over to Julian Assange, who continues to leak the information in a way that is clearly designed to help one campaign and hurt the other. Trumpâ€™s second campaign manager, Paul Manafort, flamed out in August because of his shady business dealings with the pro-Kremlin side of Ukraine, and Trump himself continues to say absurd things about Russia and Putin, like publicly inviting the Russian government to continue hacking American servers. Washington was in full Hunt for Red October mode, and it was all I could do to stay on Pageâ€™s trail, which began to look more and more like an infinity sign.

I was not the only one. Seemingly everyone I talked to had also talked to the Washington Post, and then there were these corporate investigators who drew a dark and complex web of Pageâ€™s connections. Then there was Page, praising Putin. I found myself juggling two mutually contradictory Page narratives: Was Page, like Manafort, followed by a long train of sordid dealings with dark and powerful players with deep pockets and deep resentments toward the West? This was the person described by the corporate investigators trying to whisper into my ear. Was Page a man wheeling and dealing in energy contracts with China and Turkmenistan, who was a vehicle for the Kremlin to influence the American election? Was he a man who, during a three-day trip to Moscow, met with two of Russiaâ€™s most powerful men and was now being investigated for it?

But it was hard to see that man when I actually talked to people who knew him. Page made his way into the financial sector as it ballooned in the early part of the past decade, securing a spot at Merrill Lynchâ€™s London and Moscow offices. Today, he claims he was cozy with Gazprom executives; his former colleagues laugh at the suggestion. â€œNo one let him into Gazprom,â€ Aleksashenko says. â€œHe didnâ€™t go shake [Gazprom chief Alexey] Millerâ€™s hand. He made sure there were cars, hotels and meetings for investors in London.â€ Another of Pageâ€™s colleagues from Merrill Lynch confirmed that Pageâ€™s role was simply arranging meetings between Gazprom and Western investors, something normally done by analysts, the lowest rank on the totem pole. â€œPeople organize meetings with Gazprom all the time,â€ the former colleague said. â€œHe hosted these guys in New York City but they would have done this 10 times a yearâ€¦ I used to do this; it doesnâ€™t require all that much skill. You just send out an email to 20 people saying Gazprom agreed to dinner at this place at 8 p.m., do you want to come? The main thing is just getting those two [Gazprom] guys to agree. But because they agreed doesnâ€™t mean theyâ€™re close to him.â€

But the meetings did provide him with something else. â€œGazprom didnâ€™t need money at the time,â€ says the former colleague. â€œThey were the most profitable company at the time. Their net profit was something like $36 billion a year. Their problem was not getting investors, but figuring out how to spend money in a non-efficient way if you read between the lines. He was probably aware of that. He would have known how inefficient and wasteful the company is.â€ Page became an investor in the company, and has, according to filings, advised other companies heâ€™s worked for to invest in them.

After Merrill Lynch, Page tried to set up his own fund to invest in energy projects and called it Global Energy Capital. But he tried to do this in 2008, and we know what happened to the markets in 2008. The fund is registered to his fatherâ€™s address in Poughkeepsie; Page listed himself as â€œfounder and managing partner,â€ even though the only other partner seemed to be Sergei Yatsenko, who was once a mid-level executive at Gazprom. He also maintained a website and handed out business cards that listed a fancy Madison Avenue addressâ€”thatâ€™s the one â€œaround the corner from Trump Towerâ€â€” which was actually the address of a co-working space.

â€œThatâ€™s Carter Page,â€ says an American businessman who has spent nearly a decade working in Russia. â€œThatâ€™s what heâ€™s been doing, without any actual funding, without any actual experience, without any actual connections or core capabilities, heâ€™s been trying to throw together these deals. Heâ€™s always been operating at a level far beneath that at which business in Russia is done. I admire that, it takes a lot of gumption.â€

In the interest of due diligence, I also tried to run down the rumors being handed me by the corporate investigators: that Russiaâ€™s Alfa Bank paid for the trip as a favor to the Kremlin; that Page met with Sechin and Ivanov in Moscow; that he is now being investigated by the FBI for those meetings because Sechin and Ivanov were both sanctioned for Russiaâ€™s invasion of Ukraine.

â€œI donâ€™t know this person,â€ said Pyotr Aven, one of the two founders of Alfa Bank, which is considered the Western Russian bank. Aven and his partner, Mikhail Fridman, have transferred much of their assets out of Russia and have been quite critical of Putin. As for who paid for Pageâ€™s trip, Aven was no less irritated by the question. â€œI give them money, I donâ€™t know how they spend it, who they invite, when they invite them, I have no idea,â€ he said of the New Economic School, which hosted Page and of which Aven is the main benefactor. Exasperated by my questions, he snapped, â€œDonâ€™t bring these Russian-style conspiracy theories to me.â€

â€œYou are engaged in onanism,â€ said Leontiev, the spokesman for Rosneft and Sechin when I asked him if Page had met with Sechin. â€œItâ€™s bullshit. Just bullshit. You need to understand who Sechin is to even ask this question. Itâ€™s hard to have a meeting with him at all. Itâ€™s absurd.â€

As for the FBI investigation, well, itâ€™s unclear. A State Department official who works on Russia sanctions but was not authorized to speak on the record told me that, for one thing, there is â€œno prohibition meeting with a designated [sanctioned] individual. Moreover, sanctions violations are not criminal in nature and not enforced by the FBI. OFAC runs them.â€ He added, â€œthe story doesn't add up.â€ What does seem to have happened is that various U.S. intelligence agencies were looking into Pageâ€™s time in Moscow, then briefed Senate minority leader, Democrat Harry Reid, who wrote a letter to FBI Director James Comey asking him to investigate, among other things, â€œwhether a Trump advisor who has been highly critical of U.S. and European economic sanctions on Russia, and who has conflicts of interest due to investments in Russian energy conglomerate Gazprom, met with high-ranking sanctioned individuals while in Moscow in July of 2016, well after Trump became the presumptive Republican nominee.â€

***

I got my next surprise when I called Stephen Miller, Trumpâ€™s senior adviser. I caught him just as the Trump plane was about to take off, and asked him the tired, old question: Who is Carter Page?

â€œWho?â€ says Miller, and then went off the record to expound on his lack of involvement in the campaign.

â€œHe has no formal role in the campaign,â€ Hope Hicks texted responding to my question.

Now my interest was piqued. There were whispers all over Washington that, despite Hicksâ€™s denial, Page was not only still part of the Trump campaign, but its conduit for Russian influence. Was he?

One way to answer the question was to figure out how he even got on that list to begin with.

One source suggested to me that Richard Burt, former U.S. ambassador to Germany, START treaty negotiator, and longtime lobbyist for Alfa Bank, was the nexus. It was Burt who helped draft Trumpâ€™s foreign policy speech in April, and had been advising the Trump campaign, via Senator Jeff Sessions, on foreign policy. But when I met Burt at his office at the McLarty Associates lobbying shop, he looked at me and said he had never even met him. â€œThe only person I talked to about Carter Page is this guy at the Washington Post,â€ Burt told me. â€œAnd I told him Iâ€™d never met the guy. Let me put it this way: if I have met him, Iâ€™ve forgotten. Heâ€™s the former Merrill Lynch guy, right?â€

Someone else told me that the Page connection was Rick Dearborn, Sessionsâ€™ chief of staff, who hired Page because Dearborn knew nothing about foreign policy but needed to put together a foreign policy staff for Trumpâ€™s Alexandria, Virginia, policy shop and he happened to know Page. But Dearborn wouldnâ€™t return my calls, and someone who once worked for that policy shop told me it was neither Dearborn nor Burt, but campaign co-chair Sam Clovis who recruited Page. â€œIf he was part of that original group of people, I can say with 70 percent confidence it was Sam Clovis,â€ this person told me.

â€œIâ€™m not answering your questions,â€ Clovis told me. He refused to tell me if he was the one who found Page, but Jason Miller, the campaignâ€™s other spokesperson, says, â€œCarter Page isnâ€™t someone Iâ€™ve interacted with.â€ Which confirmed what a policy staffer on the Trump campaign told me: â€œCarter is a red herring, not a Rasputin. Heâ€™s never met Trump, never briefed him. He has zero influence, none.â€

***

Was Page the shadowy messenger between the Kremlin and Trump Tower, or was he the nebbishy, not-very-successful man trying to profit from the arbitrage between what Trump saidâ€”heâ€™s my adviserâ€”and what his associates saidâ€”â€œWho?â€ Maybe I wasnâ€™t doing this right, and maybe everyone was lying to me, but it was hard not to come to the conclusion that, regardless of whatever game the Russians were running, Page was firmly in the latter camp.

â€œI donâ€™t know about his Russia fund, other than itâ€™s never really materialized,â€ says the prominent player in the energy space whom Page has pitched on various energy projects. â€œEvery conversation Iâ€™ve had with Carter has not been terribly serious. Theyâ€™ve all been pie-in-the-sky ideas. There are usually issues with traction and execution capabilities.â€ He went on. â€œI couldnâ€™t name a project that I could connect Carterâ€™s name to, any project that actually happened.â€

â€œI donâ€™t know how heâ€™s earned a living off this,â€ the energy player says, â€œbut I think heâ€™s been trying to be an intermediary. If you hang around Russia long enough, itâ€™s sort of like a pinball machine, something will hit you.â€

Strangely, it was not a Russian pinball that hit him; it was Trump. According to the Trump policy adviser, this winter, Clovis began to draw up a list of people who could serve as policy advisers to the campaign and give it some intellectual and policy heft. At a time when established Republican foreign policy specialists were tripping over each other to get away from Trump, â€œa lot of people came to Sam Clovis in February, March, and said, â€˜I want to be part of the team,â€™â€ says the Trump adviser. And thatâ€™s how it happened. â€œHeâ€™s just a guy on a list. Trump looked at the list and said, â€˜Heâ€™s an adviser.â€™ And now heâ€™s milking it for all itâ€™s worth.â€

Now, someone whom no one in the field had ever heard of was suddenly a Very Important Person in Washingtonâ€”or at least could plausibly market himself as one. â€œI was not aware of him at all until he was named to the campaign, and even after that, I had never heard of him,â€ one Russia specialist in Washington told me. He saw Page at a Washington roundtable in June for Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi, and what he saw was a strange kind of person: one who was very differential to everyone there â€œin a way that someone who is junior would use it to network,â€ but who was dropping hints full of meaning to anyone who would listenâ€”and be impressed. â€œHe was saying he was planning to go to Moscow,â€ the Russia specialist recalls. â€œHe didnâ€™t say what he was going to do there, but he created the impression that there could be some meaning to the trip.â€

According to a congressional leadership staffer familiar with the intelligence briefings on Pageâ€™s trip to Russia, â€œthe meetings did happen and thatâ€™s been established as a fact. I think the investigation is more what happened in them.â€ But it remained unclear, the staffer told me unprompted, what this even meant. â€œItâ€™s not just did he met with them or not, but now looking into the bigger question of what the hell is going on?â€ said the staffer. â€œIs he acting as a conduit in ways that are against Americaâ€™s national security interests? Wittingly or un-, I should add. Itâ€™s whatâ€™s hard to parse about this. Is he doing this with nefarious intent or is this just about guys who are thrilled to be living in a John le CarrÃ© novel? Or are they being played by much smarter people in the Kremlin?â€

This seems to be vintage Carter Page, a man whose story never quite adds up, as much as he tries to make the numbers work. But heâ€™s also mastered the art of manipulating the distance between his story as it is and his story as he wants it to be, playing on the uncertainty in between to make himself seem more successful, more connected, even more evil than he really isâ€”and to try to turn a profit off of that. â€œIf Page using his status as â€˜Trump advisorâ€™ for personal gain, thatâ€™s another matter: Time for Page to join Twitter!â€ Michael McFaul, former U.S. ambassador to Russia, tweeted after news of the investigation broke. The Russians may be feeling out the Trump campaign via Page, but Page must be loving every minute of it. After all, meeting Russiaâ€™s energy czar is an impossible dream for a would-be investor struggling to make it in the world of Russian energyâ€”but the dream entered the realm of the possible when Trump said three words in March: â€œCarter Page, Ph.D.â€ Now Carter Page, Ph.D., has found a perfect candidate to latch on to, like a pilot fish feeding off the carnage wrought by the oblivious Trump shark.

For months now, the American press has been twisting itself in knots trying to explain men like Page and Manafort, and, through them, to answer the questions of whether Putin is trying to destroy America by their hands, and is Trump a Kremlin stooge or a just a useful idiot, and is there even a difference?

There doesnâ€™t seem to be one in the world of Trump, which in some ways resembles Putinâ€™s: the waters of truth are muddy and deeply suggestive. And that is all that matters. Is Putin actually meddling in our election and undermining the foundations of Western democracy in a massive way, or doing just enough to make us think he is, and thereby acquiring powers he holds only because we believe him to have them? â€œI want to hope that this is connected with the growing influence and significance of Russia,â€ Putin says of the rumors of Russian meddling in the American electionâ€”as we in the media continue to squeegee them around, rarely really getting closer to the truth, and watching it disintegrate in our hands when we think weâ€™ve finally grasped it.

Julia Ioffe is contributing writer at Politico Magazine.

title: Itâ€™s â€œTrump is HITLERâ€ Month at the Washington Post â€“ Eagle Rising
summary:
Like much of the mainstream media, the Washington Post is going out of its way to disparage Donald Trump. But the Post isnâ€™t satisfied with the normal biased reportingâ€”they have gone above and beyond assigning 20 reporters just to dig up dirt on the Republican nominee. That must have failed because now they are taking the lazy, but disgusting way out with inappropriate Hitler references. Twice in this month Post columnists have compared Donald Trump to Adolf Hitler. Perhaps the editors have designated September as â€œTrump Is Hitler Monthâ€ at the Washington Post.

On Monday they featured a column by Richard Cohen which said in part,

(â€¦) while Trump is neither an anti-Semite nor does he have designs on neighboring countries, he is Hitlerian in his thinking. He thinks the truth is what he says it is.

Mr. Cohen didnâ€™t mention what despot Hillaryâ€™s lies reminded him of, but then again the post would never have a â€œHillary is Hitler month.â€ While a Hillary comparison would be just as wrong, the fact that they are only creating a â€œTrumpâ€ month is incredibly sexist.

Six Dayâ€™s before Mr. Cohen, another columnist Shalom Auslander wrote, â€œDonâ€™t compare Donald Trump to Adolf Hitler. It belittlesâ€¦

The views expressed in this opinion article are solely those of their author and are not necessarily either shared or endorsed by EagleRising

title: Obamaâ€™s team isnâ€™t laughing at Trump anymore
summary:
2016 Obamaâ€™s team isnâ€™t laughing at Trump anymore The presidentâ€™s aides worry the Republican represents more of America than a fringe.

Obamaworld laughed as it watched Donald Trumpâ€™s hostile takeover of the GOP. After eight years of Republican opposition, inconsistent policy demands and racialized hate against the first black president, President Barack Obamaâ€™s aides, past and present, thought Republicans had gotten what they deserved--and more, all but forfeiting the 2016 race to the woman they defeated eight years ago.

Theyâ€™re not laughing anymore.

Story Continued Below

Going into Monday nightâ€™s debate, Obamaâ€™s team is feeling that same anxiety expressed by some top Hillary Clinton aides: maybe the country isnâ€™t what they thought, maybe the resistance to Obamacare and gay marriage and the progress theyâ€™re so proud of is broader than the vocal fringe theyâ€™ve always dismissed. Maybe, the presidentâ€™s aides â€“ current and former â€“ now concede, theyâ€™re going to have to live with the fact that Trump could end up in the Oval Office in part due to a backlash against Obama.

â€œIâ€™m trying to think of a series to compare it to, which was a series that started as a comedy and became a high stakes drama,â€ said Ben LaBolt, a former White House aide and press secretary for Obamaâ€™s 2012 reelection campaign. â€œI feel like weâ€™re maybe in the fifth season of â€˜Breaking Badâ€™ here. Weâ€™re way beyond the laughs, and just sitting on the edge of our seats in terror.â€

â€œThere's not a lot of mirth in the circles I run in about him,â€ said another former senior Obama campaign staffer.

Privately, Obama has expressed mixed feelings, according to people close to the president. Heâ€™s still nursing amusement at Republicans for being hapless enough to get railroaded by Trump, but itâ€™s mixed with frustration that there are so many Americans he failed to reach. People who've spoken to him say the president wonders what he might have done differently to break through in a way that would make people whoâ€™ve benefited from his policiesâ€”like those enjoying added health benefits courtesy of Obamacareâ€”support Democrats.

For Obamaworld staffers who had just been starting to settle into a new buoyancy about the president's climbing approval numbers, Trumpâ€™s growing strength is an agonizing reminder of how far short they have fallen in delivering on â€˜hope.' Even if Clinton wins, the Republican has shown not only that America is divided between red and blue but that thereâ€™s an America that Obama never connected with at all, and where all his data and rational arguments and appeals to sensibilities are as useless as Monopoly money.

â€œWe are still the country that elected Barack Obama in 2008, and we are capable of that and more,â€ said Jim Papa, a former special assistant for legislative affairs in the White House. â€œBut weâ€™re also capable of making bad choices and being seduced by someone who plays to fears and anxieties and racial differences.â€

Trumpâ€™s already done things they never thought he could, like mainstreaming racist rhetoric and racking up so many small donors that they worry about the extent of his support. And that was even before he riled up Obama doubters again with his birther pirouette.

And the result: Trumpâ€™s doing better in the polls at this late stage than Obamaâ€™s team imagined. With 43 days to go, Trump and Clinton are essentially tied, polls sitting within the margin of error, even in battleground states.

Though only a few weeks ago, current and former Obama aides would joke about how the presidentâ€™s great political legacy might be the Republican Party destroying itself in front of him. Now, on the record, they push back on the very suggestion that Obamaâ€™s legacy should be viewed in any frame that Trump also occupies.

â€œI donâ€™t think he thinks itâ€™s his legacy, I donâ€™t think any of us think itâ€™s his legacy,â€ said Dan Pfeiffer, a former senior adviser to the president. â€œTrumpism is a lot of things in this country. President Obama is the face of that for some Republicans, but the Republican Party got themselves into this mess.â€

But they worry about what even a Trump loss says about Obamaâ€™s America.

â€œI think he will lose badly in this election, but I think the impact heâ€™s had on our political process is incredibly damaging, and will be lasting,â€ said Tommy Vietor, a former national security spokesman who noted that his own amusement at Trump ended a year ago. â€œHeâ€™s made us look stupid. I think he is stupid.â€

For any efforts Obama made in urging people to disagree without being disagreeable, as the president likes to say, â€œTrump has shattered that,â€ Vietor said. â€œHe has brought back a brand of politics that is you punch your opponent as hard as you can, it doesnâ€™t matter if itâ€™s a low blow, it doesnâ€™t matter if itâ€™s not of substance. Thatâ€™s a bad lesson for people to learn.â€

According to Earnest, Obama is serious about wanting a functional opposition and wishes that heâ€™d had one to negotiate with on immigration reform, trade, infrastructure and other priorities. The sense of lost opportunity eats at them, as does the sense that itâ€™s not going away, despite their confidence in Clintonâ€™s chances.

â€œIâ€™m not saying weâ€™d all be playing acoustic guitar in a circle on the National Mall, but I am saying we would have progress to show for our efforts,â€ said White House press secretary Josh Earnest, who's been with the president since the first campaign.

Not everyoneâ€™s inside Obamaworld is down. Some schadenfreude remains.

â€œHe's still exposed and ripped apart factions of the GOP, enhanced their brand as hostile to a rising electorates, and will leave them with no infrastructure,â€ said a more upbeat former Obama 2008 campaign spokesman Hari Sevugan.

And Democratsâ€™ sense of the vacuous GOP that Trump represents continues to resonate, particularly as they see the Republican nominee attack an economy thatâ€™s gone wrong with the support of many of the same people who opposed the policies that the president credits for the economic rebound that includes the longest period of sustained growth and taxpayers repaid with interest from the bailouts that caused so much trouble.

â€œThe eight-year legacy of the recovery from the Great Recession is clear evidence that the Tea Party movement,â€ said Earnest, â€œis intellectually bankruptâ€”or about something other than the economy.â€

But that doesn't take care of their grief about the state of American politics.

â€œIâ€™d rather live in a world where the two parties really compete,â€ Papa said, â€œthan have a political edge on the Republican Party but have to live in a world where white supremacists have a channel and are legitimized.â€

title: Georgia poll: Donald Trump, Hillary Clinton in tight race
summary:
Story highlights Trump has 45%, Clinton 42% and Gary Johnson 8%

Mitt Romney won the state by 8 points in 2012

Washington (CNN) Donald Trump and Hillary Clinton are in a tight race in in Georgia, a traditionally deep red state, according to a new poll.

The Republican candidate has 45% to Clinton's 42% in the Monmouth University poll, within the poll's margin of error. Libertarian Gary Johnson had the support of 8% of likely voters.

Trump is underperforming previous GOP candidates. Mitt Romney won the state by 8 points in 2012 over President Barack Obama.

The incumbent Republican senator is also out-polling Trump. Sen. Johnny Isakson has a 16-point lead over challenger Jim Barksdale, 50% to 34%.

Clinton's strength comes from the Atlanta area, where she leads Trump 55% to 35%. But Trump leads her 51% to 33% elsewhere in the Peach State. She leads 88% to 4% among the state's black voters, but trails 20% to 66% among white voters.

Read More

There may be a few women out there who enjoy a man telling them to be more joyous in their presence, but as for the rest of us, thereâ€™s nothing a woman hates more than being told to smile.

title: Is Donald Trump qualified to be president?
summary:
Off Message Is Donald Trump qualified to be president? In the most pivotal moment of 2016, these are the questions he must answer.

H.L. Mencken declared there was only one way to look at a politician â€” â€œdown.â€

Likewise, thereâ€™s really only one way to look at the first presidential debate on Monday: as the first serious job interview for potential President Donald John Trump â€” an opaque candidate who has hidden behind a steel curtain of one-liners, faux familiarity and universal celebrity.

Story Continued Below

Yeah, yeah, yeah, itâ€™s a big night for Hillary Clinton too. Sheâ€™s got a lot to prove, for real, namely that sheâ€™s not the lying, self-dealing crook many Americans think she is â€” or at least convince the 55 percent of voters who donâ€™t like her that her virtues (temperament and experience) compensate for decades of assorted ick. She needs to prove she can stand up to Trump, answer the usual email/foundation questions, convince whoeverâ€™s still sellable on the idea (stop Instagramming a picture of your lunch, millennials, and listen up) that sheâ€™s not some scheming granny who will just sell everybody out the second John Roberts drops the swearing-in Bible.

But the spotlight belongs on Trump, who is in need of a rigorous job interview. Clinton deserves the same, but she is already the single most scrutinized, parsed, vetted, investigated, attacked and plaudited non-incumbent to ever seek the presidency. Sheâ€™s been around forever, making enemies since the internet was dial-up, cell phones were the size of skateboards and Trump was engaged to Marla Maples.

Everyone makes the orange jokes, but Trump is something of a black box â€” running on a few big and broad ideas (curbing illegal immigration, ditching bad trade deals, restoring American prosperity to the working class and obliterating political correctness). Heâ€™s bad with facts and the truth, and perhaps worse, takes perverse pride in being a D student who doesnâ€™t read books, has the sketchiest sense of history, doesnâ€™t read briefing materials, and, according to aides and ghostwriters, canâ€™t even sit still long enough to be given a thorough verbal briefing.

These are not nasty, biased, liberal opinions. They are facts based on reporting and Trumpâ€™s own public performances. Here are five questions Trump needs to address on Monday â€” but taken together, they add up to one big one: Is Donald Trump qualified to be President of the United States?

1. Does he actually know â€” or care to know â€” the basic information needed to competently run the country?

Only one verdict of presidential fitness counts, of course, and thatâ€™s a candidateâ€™s capacity to get to 270 electoral votes. In recent days, Trump â€” who swooned after Clintonâ€™s superb convention in Philly â€” has closed to within the margin of error in many (though not all) national polls, and jumped to serious leads in battlegrounds like Ohio and Iowa since Aug. 1. Heâ€™s still the most unpopular candidate in recent history (although Clinton is number two with a bullet) and seems to have a ceiling of between 40 and 44 percent nationally. But he can win. Fivethirtyeight, the arch-aggregator, gives Trump nearly a 50 percent chance of prevailing.

His resurgence proves three political points â€” two of them we knew, the third is a surprise to everyone except Trump and his team: The country (especially the white working-class parts) is pissed, Clinton is a perennially lousy candidate and â€” lastly, but not leastly â€” Trump has proven to be a resilient and flexible candidate with the capacity (developed late in the game) to shift shape and shut up when he needs to.

The first debate should be a pivot â€” from politicking to president-ing. Being a cunning candidate isnâ€™t remotely the same thing as being ready to rule â€” and we should be moving to the Doris Kearns Goodwin phase of the campaign, where the top priority is fitness to govern in a time of trial. It probably wonâ€™t happen, but a boy can dream.

This is not to suggest that Trump canâ€™t do the job (Ronald Reagan, another entertainer who forayed into politics, was mostly a success), but heâ€™s been judged as a performer up to this point, and not subjected to the cold fluorescent scrutiny of managerial competence.

Trump has repeatedly flubbed tests of his basic understanding of domestic and foreign affairs â€” apparently he wasnâ€™t aware Russia had annexed Crimea until George Stephanopoulos informed him recently. He obliterated Jeb Bush, that humbled patsy of the GOP establishment, in the debates â€” but Bush (if anyone had cared to listen) punctured Trumpâ€™s bully-boy promise to impose tariffs on Chinese products, correctly pointing out that such a move would certainly spark countermeasures by Beijing that could lead to a global depression. Trump wasnâ€™t aware of that fact, or just didnâ€™t care.

The caring part is kind of important, if history is any guide. In April, I sat down with one of his longtime advisers, Roger Stone, who described what it was like to brief an executive whose prime attributes were supreme self-confidence and supreme impatience. â€œAll you can do is present information and let him either assimilate it or not,â€ said Stone, who has known the GOP nominee for decades. â€œWhen you write something for him, keep it short and staccato. He's not going to read a 40-page white paper on the economy; zero chance of that. It's just too boring. Don't blame him; I don't like it either. So keep it simple and direct because that's the way he communicates.â€

Stone argued that Trump isnâ€™t an ignoramus â€” just a cut-to-the-chase decision-maker who is a lightning-quick study. But George W. Bushâ€™s advisers, speaking to biographer Peter Baker, said that Bushâ€™s unwillingness to ask probing, informed questions led to some of his disastrous decisions in Iraq. And during the nadir of the 2009 global economic meltdown, President Obama added a daily economic briefing to his daily national security rundown to keep tabs on the rapidly shifting metrics of crisis.

Trumpâ€™s capacity to intuitively assimilate information might render such processes useless â€” but thereâ€™s not a single presidential historian drawing oxygen who believes a lack of intellectual curiosity is an asset for the job.

Many Americans might not give a damn that he knows what HUDâ€™s Section 8 program is â€” and his failure to answer informational questions that Clinton would parry with ease will endear him to his screw-the-media base. But donâ€™t people have the right to know what he actually knows? Trump has gleefully trashed the rules of presidential campaigns, so why should a moderator treat him with the deference of someone who abides by the norms â€” by assuming he possesses the basic knowledge traditionally required of a presidential candidate?

2. Does Trump understand and respect the basic principles and traditions of American Constitutional government?

Again, this is not a given. Hillary Clinton despises the press, and dodges them as if they were a pack of feral rats, but she has never suggested they be stopped from doing their jobs through the courts. Trump (who banned news outlets, including this one, from his events for most of the campaign) routinely threatens litigation against publications that publish unflattering articles and, in February, went so far as to say: â€œWe're going to open up those libel laws. So when The New York Times writes a hit piece which is a total disgrace â€¦ we can sue them and win money instead of having no chance of winning because they're totally protected.â€

Thatâ€™s a new one for a presidential nominee. As Corey Brettschneider wrote in POLITICO Magazine last month: â€œFor more than 50 years, the Supreme Court has held that for a public figure to prove libel against a news outlet, they must show that the outlet acted with â€˜actual maliceâ€™ â€” that is, with knowledge that it was false or with reckless disregard of whether it was false or not.â€

During a private meeting with Hill Republicans earlier this year, the populist real estate developer expressed his fondness for â€œArticle 12 of the Constitution.â€ The framers stopped at seven. â€œHe was just listing out numbers,â€ said Congressman Blake Farenthold (R-Texas), a Trump backer at the time. â€œI think he was confusing Articles and Amendments.â€

OK, letâ€™s write that one off as a gotcha â€” you can understand Constitutional principles without citing literal chapter and verse. But consider his reaction to the Paris bombings last November when Trump told FOX News he thought the government should shutter some mosques where â€œsome bad things are happening.â€ The comment was decried by Constitutional scholars of all stripes as a radical measure that would violate the â€œFree Exerciseâ€ clause of the First Amendment, a pillar of protection for faiths of all kinds.

3. Why wonâ€™t Trump forthrightly answer the most basic questions about his businesses and debts?

Hillary Clinton has, appropriately, has come under intense scrutiny for her six-figure speeches to big Wall Street firms like Goldman Sachs â€” and has refused to release the transcripts of her prattles to the plutocrats. And serious questions remain about the lack of boundaries between the Clinton Foundation, the State Department, and big-money foreign donors who blurred the line between influence peddling and altruism.

But the Clintons have released all of their tax returns (in part because, for many years, they were required to do so as government employees) and Trump is the first major presidential candidate in the modern era to thumb his nose at handing over a single one.

Why does it matter? Because a guy whose purchase on the presidency is rooted in his private-sector acumen needs to back up his claims with proof, in the same way that Clinton needs to be held accountable for her purported record of accomplishment in the White House, Senate and State Department. At issue is Trumpâ€™s fundamental personal narrative, and his claim that heâ€™s â€œvery, very rich.â€ He is, but maybe not quite as much as he claims (he says heâ€™s good for $11 billion; Forbes and other outlets say heâ€™s worth less than half that much).

More serious is the issue of Trumpâ€™s debts: The Clinton campaign, citing press reports that he owes large sums to overseas creditors in China and elsewhere, has attacked him for being in the pocket of foreign financial overlords. If thatâ€™s a lie, thereâ€™s an easy way to prove it â€” by releasing the returns.

This isnâ€™t a liberal media witch-hunt: Many Republicans, including supporters like House Speaker Paul Ryan, say he needs to cough them up, and fast.

4. Whatâ€™s the deal with his charitable foundation? Then thereâ€™s the matter of Trumpâ€™s sloppily run, and less-than-magnanimous foundation. In exposÃ© after exposÃ©, Washington Post reporter David Fahrenthold has reported on a pattern of over-promising donations and the misuse of funds (including a quarter-million payment to cover legal fees for Trumpâ€™s businesses and sports memorabilia) that Trump himself has conceded might be illegal.

The problem, yet again, is that Trump has refused to release a comprehensive accounting of his giving, and his surrogates have routinely misstated the magnitude of his generosity, according to the reporting of Fahrenthold and others.

5. Why lie? These days, the polygraph is used sparingly as part of the vetting process for employment, mostly for sensitive national security or law enforcement jobs. If presidential candidates were subjected to that level of scrutiny, the only person allowed on the debate stage at Hofstra would be the technician testing the sound system.

But if Trump is to be vetted for the presidency, he needs to be asked not only about individual statements heâ€™s made in the past, but his pattern of lying, stretching the truth and bungling facts.

Hillary Clinton (â€œCrooked Hillaryâ€ in Trumpâ€™s parlance) it bears repeating, is no saint â€” far from it â€” and her early answers on the email scandal were misleading, bordering on the untruthful, and flat-out lies in the view of GOP congressional investigators.

But itâ€™s a crowning irony of 2016 that the Republican Party, whose base revolted against its leadership for untruthfulness â€” especially George W. Bushâ€™s claims about Iraq â€” would nominate the most brazenly truth-challenged candidate in recent history. (A recitation of Trumpâ€™s whoppers would take up too much space â€“ read POLITICOâ€™s comprehensive â€œDonald Trumpâ€™s Week of Misrepresentations, Exaggerations and Half-Truthsâ€ for a taste.)

In an attempt to defend Trump, buddy Newt Gingrich, who lobbied to be Trumpâ€™s running mate, tweeted what amounted to an indirect admission that his man has a trouble with all those pesky facts. â€œClinton,â€ the former speaker wrote, â€œis a fox who knows many things you can fact check. Trump is a hedgehog who knows one big thingâ€¦â€

But getting the facts right â€” and telling the truth â€” is a big thing. Itâ€™s the only way citizens will ever look up to, and not down on, their leaders.

Authors:
authors: Jack Shafer,Kyle Cheney,Daniel Strauss,Daniel Lippman,Eli Stokols,Glenn Thrush,Brent Griffiths

title: Trump Just Insulted Millions Who Lost Everything In Bush's Recession, "That's Just Business"
summary:
16.8k SHARES SHARE THIS STORY

Hillary Clinton just called out the fact that Donald Trump cheered for the housing crisis in anticipation of its collapse â€“ which is absolutely true. Trump told The Globe and Mail in March of 2007: â€œPeople have been talking about the end of the cycle for 12 years, and Iâ€™m excited if it is. Iâ€™ve always made more money in bad markets than in good markets.â€

In fact, Trump thought the housing crisis was much-ado-do about nothing for high-end investments, and told investors: â€œI donâ€™t see the subprime problems affecting the higher-end stuffâ€¦In fact, he is advising investors that there are now great deals in buying subprime mortgages at a discount and repossessed houses at low prices.â€

Of course, on one level, Trump wasnâ€™t wrongÂ­Â­â€”in that the subprime crisis affected mostly poorer Americans who lost their homes and jobs and the ability to support their families. The collapse of home prices caused by the housing bubble cost roughly seven million Americans more than $7 trillion in equity during the Great Recession.

This recession most severely impacted low-income folks â€“ people who are burdened with payments in excess of 50 percent of their income â€“ Trumpâ€™s response is just â€œThatâ€™s called business.â€

Add your name to millions demanding that Congress take action on the Presidentâ€™s crimes. IMPEACH DONALD TRUMP!

title: Famous dog killed in spot she waited a year for her owner to return to! [VIDEO]
summary:
Famous dog killed in spot she waited a year for her owner to return to! [VIDEO]

Animal lovers, get your tissues ready, because you are about to bawl your eyes out, especially if you are a dog lover.

You know what? Donâ€™t even read further if you are part of the manâ€™s best friend club, you just might regret your decision to get out of bed this morning. News just hit the web that the locally famous three year-old dog named Loung, who fell out of a truck last year, landing on a busy route between Cambodia and Thailand, has been hit and killed by a car as it waited for the return of its owner for over a year.

You can start the waterworks as we go into the details. The Sukhumvit Road, or Thailand Route 3, is a leading highway between Bangkok and Cambodia and Loungâ€™s owner must not have realized that she had fallen right out of the truck. Whatâ€™s truly amazing is that the dog refused to leave the area, hoping that one day her owner would return and rescue her.

Ã— 101 Things All Young Adults Should Know by Sir John Hawkins John Hawkins's book 101 Things All Young Adults Should Know is filled with lessons that newly minted adults need in order to get the most out of life. Local people in the village of Ban Nong Khon in Chanthaburi province took the responsibility of feeding her as she waited for her owner. After some time had passed, Loung became somewhat of a celebrity for the locals and tourists, with many people stopping by weekly to take a photo with the lone dog.

Many people would occasionally stop by the highway, claiming to be Loungâ€™s true owners, but would be met with timidness and distrust, she would run off into the jungle as soon as someone tried to leash her up to take her.

Loung unfortunately met her end last week, with many photos of the dead and bloodied dog being released in the newspaper. That distasteful act caused so much outrage from many locals and social media users that the media companies took the photos down. The story has been going viral ever since.
